{{also|恭喜发财}}
==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|s=恭喜发财|type=22|to congratulate, respectfully wishing one joy|to become rich, to make money|lit=congratulations for becoming rich}}
{{was fwotd|2013|February|10|lang=zh}}

===Etymology===
Originated in post-{{w|Opium War}} Guangzhou Cantonese, now a general Chinese phrase.

===Pronunciation===
{{zh-pron
|m=gōngxǐ fācái
|c=gung1 hei2 faat3 coi4
|h=pfs=kiûng-hí fat-chhòi
|mn=kiong-hí hoat-châi
|w=1kun xi+4faq+3ze
|cat=ph
}}

===Phrase===
{{zh-phrase}}

# [[Happy New Year]] (congratulations and best wishes for a prosperous New Year)
#* {{zh-x|恭喜發財，紅包 拿 來！|(''a cheeky request for a red packet of lucky money'')}}
#* {{zh-x|恭喜發財，利{lai6}市{si6} 𢭃{dau6} 來！|(''a cheeky request for a red packet of lucky money'')|C-GZ}}
#* {{zh-x|他 喜歡 於 大年 初 一 打 電話 給 一 家 酒樓，因為 他 明 知道 接 電話 的 小姐 拿 起 聽筒 後 說 的 第 一 句 話 必 是「恭喜發財」，@^周 @^石 先生 連忙 回應「多謝 多謝」，然後 馬上 收線；純粹 為 了 取 個 好 意頭，不 為 幫襯。|He liked to call a restaurant on every New Year's Day (of the lunar calendar), as he knew clearly the lady there answering the phone would inevitably greet him with "'''Kung Hei Fat Choi'''". Upon hearing this he (Zhou Shi) would promptly reply by saying "Thank you, thank you" and then just hang up. His reason for doing this was just to get an auspicious start of the new year, not an act of patronisation."|ref=馬家輝，《[http://books.google.com.au/books?id=sM-84rZTd5gC&pg=PA62&dq=恭喜發財 我們──關於這個時代的一些喜悅與憂傷]》 (Ma Jiahui, "''Us - Some Happiness and Sadness about This Era''")}}
